title: Inmates who beat triple murderer Douglas Garland in jail will be charged, police say - Calgary - CBC News
text:
Inmates who beat triple murderer Douglas Garland in jail will be charged, police say Calgary police say several inmates face assault charges By Meghan Grant, CBC News Posted: Feb 21, 2017 2:04 PM MT Last Updated: Feb 21, 2017 2:17 PM MT Charges are pending against the men accused of beating Douglas Garland at the remand centre Friday night. (CBC) Related Stories 'Cunning, cruel' murderer Douglas Garland can't apply for parole for 75 years: judge 
Charges are pending against several inmates at the Calgary Remand Centre in a serious beating that injured Douglas Garland just hours after he was convicted of killing a Calgary couple and their grandson. 
Garland, 57, was returned to the remand centre on the weekend after he was released from hospital where he was taken following the attack by fellow inmates late Friday night. 
The beating happened after Garland was sentenced Friday to life in prison with no chance of parole for 75 years for the first-degree murders of Alvin and Kathy Liknes and their five-year-old grandson Nathan O'Brien. Douglas Garland found guilty of murdering Calgary boy and grandparents 
"Correctional centres can be a difficult, sometimes volatile environment," a spokesperson for Alberta Justice wrote in a statement. 
"Peace officers are trained professionals who both try to anticipate and prevent incidents when possible, and who react quickly and appropriately when an incident occurs. 
Calgary police confirmed Tuesday that charges are pending against several inmates and that the investigation is ongoing. 
The force wouldn't comment any role guards may have played in allowing Garland to be in harm's way. 
Placement decisions consider security needs, according to Alberta Justice, adding that inmates who are known to be incompatible are kept separate, 
Garland is expected to remain at the remand centre until being assessed for transfer to a federal institution, likely sometime next week, Garland's lawyer, Kim Ross, said on the weekend.
